Introduction

Adrenal insufficiency (AI) is characterized by inadequate production of glucocorticoids (cortisol) and/or mineralocorticoids (aldosterone) by the adrenal glands.  AI can present acutely or chronically with varying degrees of severity.

Pathophysiology and etiologies

Normal gland function and regulation



The adrenal glands, located above the kidneys, produce several essential hormones.  The outer layer, the adrenal cortex (

figure 1
), synthesizes 3 classes of hormones:



  • Glucocorticoids (primarily cortisol) exert a broad spectrum of effects (eg, fight response), including maintaining vascular tone (cortisol potentiates alpha-1 stimulation).
  • Mineralocorticoids (primarily aldosterone) help regulate blood pressure and potassium balance by promoting renal sodium retention and potassium secretion.
  • Androgens (eg, dehydroepiandrosterone [DHEA]) contribute to sexual function in females (testes are the main source of androgens in males).


The hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis is responsible for regulating glucocorticoid production (

figure 2
):



  • Stress triggers hypothalamic secretion of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH).
  • CRH stimulates the anterior pituitary to secrete adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).
  • ACTH stimulates adrenal release of cortisol (and adrenal androgens).
  • Cortisol exerts negative feedback to the hypothalamus (reducing CRH) and pituitary (reducing ACTH).


In contrast, aldosterone secretion is primarily regulated by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), not the HPA axis.  AI can result from dysfunction at any level of the HPA axis.

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease)



Primary AI occurs due to a dysfunction in the adrenal glands themselves, leading to decreased cortisol and aldosterone production.  This disorder accounts for 80%-90% of AI cases.  Etiologies include:



  • Autoimmune adrenalitis is the most common cause in resource-rich countries, particularly in patients with other autoimmune conditions (eg, polyglandular autoimmune syndrome, hypothyroidism, vitiligo).  It involves both cell-mediated autoimmunity targeting the adrenal cortex and autoantibody formation targeting multiple steroidogenic enzymes (eg, 21-hydroxylase).  Certain medications (eg, checkpoint inhibitors such as nivolumab) can trigger this process.  Histopathology typically shows atrophic adrenal glands with lymphocytic infiltration
  • Infectious adrenalitis:  Extrapulmonary tuberculosis is the most prevalent cause worldwide.  Disseminated fungal infections (eg, histoplasmosis) are another cause.
  • Adrenal hemorrhage (bilateral) has predisposing factors that include anticoagulant use, antiphospholipid syndrome, trauma, and severe sepsis (eg, Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome from meningococcemia).
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy is a rare genetic disorder primarily affecting males, characterized by the accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the adrenal cortex and nervous system.

Central adrenal insufficiency



Central AI occurs when HPA axis disruption involves either the anterior pituitary gland (secondary) or, rarely, the hypothalamus (tertiary).  The terms "central" and "secondary" are often used interchangeably given the rarity of tertiary AI.  The vast majority of cases are due to prolonged administration of exogenous glucocorticoids (

figure 3
), which can suppress CRH (hypothalamus) and ACTH (anterior pituitary).



Additional etiologies include:



  • Pituitary disease causes include pituitary tumors, infiltrative disease (eg, hemochromatosis), Sheehan syndrome (postpartum), pituitary apoplexy, autoimmune lymphocytic hypophysitis, and chronic opioid use.
  • Hypothalamic disease (rare) causes include masses (eg, craniopharyngiomas, metastatic lesions), CNS radiation, and infiltrative disease (eg, sarcoidosis).

Clinical presentation



AI can manifest with a spectrum of symptoms ranging from insidious to life-threatening, depending on the extent and rate of adrenal function loss and the severity of stress.  AI can be classified as chronic or acute (ie, adrenal crisis).  In addition, several features can differentiate between primary and central AI.

Chronic adrenal insufficiency



Clinical features common to chronic primary and central adrenal insufficiency



Chronic AI presents as an insidious course with nonspecific symptoms, including gradual onset of fatigue/weakness, weight loss/anorexia, nausea, and myalgias.



Chronic primary adrenal insufficiency



Chronic primary AI, usually resulting from autoimmune destruction of the bilateral adrenal cortex, presents with the following manifestations reflecting adrenocortical destruction:



  • Mineralocorticoid deficiency:  Reduced aldosterone causes renal sodium wasting (eg, hypotension, hypovolemia, salt cravings) and potassium retention.  Hypovolemia provides non-osmotic stimulus for antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion, leading to water retention and hyponatremia.
  • Glucocorticoid deficiency:  Decreased cortisol contributes to hypotension (cortisol enhances vascular tone), causes constitutional symptoms (eg, fatigue, anorexia), can trigger hypoglycemia, and may lead to eosinophilia (by reducing eosinophil migration into tissues).  Because cortisol normally inhibits ADH secretion, low cortisol also contributes to hyponatremia.
  • Androgen deficiency:  Reduced adrenal androgens can cause loss of libido and secondary sexual characteristics (eg, reduced pubic hair), typically only in females (testicular androgen production continues in males).


Distinguishing chronic primary from central adrenal insufficiency



Most cases of chronic AI are due to central AI in the setting of chronic glucocorticoid use (resulting in HPA axis suppression).  The adrenal cortex can still secrete aldosterone because mineralocorticoid production is regulated by the RAAS instead of the HPA axis.  Therefore, central AI is typically milder (isolated glucocorticoid deficiency) than primary AI (combined glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid deficiency).



Key differentiating features between chronic primary and central AI include:



  • Salt-craving and hypotension are less likely in central AI because of the lack of mineralocorticoid deficiencyâ€“induced renal salt wasting.
  • Hyperkalemia is not seen in central AI because aldosterone is unaffected.
  • Hyponatremia is more severe in primary AI because volume depletion (due to combined glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid deficiencies) is a strong non-osmotic stimulus for ADH release.
  • Hyperpigmentation is mainly seen in primary AI because decreased negative feedback on ACTH leads to high levels of both ACTH and its precursor, proopiomelanocortin (POMC); melanocyte-stimulating hormone is also derived from POMC.

Acute adrenal insufficiency (adrenal crisis)



Adrenal crisis is a life-threatening condition characterized by hypotension (key feature) and nonspecific symptoms including altered mental status, severe abdominal pain, nausea/vomiting, and fever.  It is typically precipitated by acutely stressful events (eg, surgery, endoscopy, injury, infection) and can develop in those with preexisting AI (primary or secondary/central).  As with chronic AI, acute primary AI tends to have a more severe presentation than acute central AI due to loss of both cortisol and aldosterone.  Cardiovascular collapse is common because cortisol is needed to maintain vascular tone and aldosterone is critical for sodium retention.



More specifically, the main driver for adrenal crisis in primary AI appears to be mineralocorticoid (aldosterone deficiency), given that it can occur even in patients taking physiologic doses of glucocorticoids.  However, the resulting severe hypotension, often refractory to volume resuscitation and poorly responsive to vasopressors, is likely exacerbated by glucocorticoid deficiency because cortisol is needed to potentiate the effect of alpha-1 stimulation on peripheral vascular tone.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of suspected AI involves a combination of clinical features, laboratory tests, and imaging studies.  In addition to identifying consistent laboratory findings as described previously (eg, hyponatremia), evaluation includes confirming a low serum cortisol and establishing the level of defect (eg, adrenals, pituitary).

Confirming cortisol deficiency



Cortisol level measurements can help confirm the diagnosis of AI.  Although typical cutoffs are listed here, the specific values may vary by laboratory and guidelines.



For suspected adrenal crisis (eg, hypotensive patient), cortisol <15 mcg/dL suggests AI, whereas â‰¥15 mcg/dL excludes it.  In suspected chronic AI, cortisol â‰¥15 mcg/dL similarly rules out the diagnosis; cortisol â‰¤5 mcg/dL is consistent with AI, and cortisol between 5-15 mcg/dL is considered indeterminate and requires an ACTH (cosyntropin) stimulation test.  The test consists of administering a dose of IV ACTH and measuring serum cortisol 30 and 60 minutes afterward:



  • Cortisol does not rise or remains low (eg, â‰¤5 mcg/dL) indicates that the adrenals are unable to respond to ACTH, making AI likely.
  • Cortisol rises (eg, â‰¥15 mcg/dL) is a normal adrenal response to ACTH, making AI unlikely.

Establish level of defect



For patients with confirmed cortisol deficiency, determining whether the insufficiency is primary (adrenal gland dysfunction) or central (pituitary or hypothalamic dysfunction) is crucial.  An early-morning serum ACTH level aids in differentiation:



  • High ACTH indicates loss of negative HPA axis feedback, suggesting primary AI.
  • Low or inappropriately normal ACTH indicates deficient ACTH secretion despite low cortisol, suggesting central AI.


Indeterminate ACTH requires further evaluation (eg, renin and aldosterone can help distinguish primary from central AI).

Evaluation of etiology



In suspected primary AI, a detailed history can reveal clues to etiology, including autoimmunity, infections, or malignancy.  If the history is not revealing, dedicated evaluation for autoimmune primary AI (eg, antiâ€“21-hydroxylase antibodies) or more unusual causes (eg, CT scan for bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, plasma VLCFAs for adrenoleukodystrophy) should be undertaken.



In suspected central AI, clinical history should first assess for exogenous glucocorticoid use discontinued within the past 3 months (particularly â‰¥5 mg prednisone daily or equivalent for â‰¥2 weeks) because most cases are due to withdrawal of exogenous glucocorticoids.  If the cause is unclear, MRI of the pituitary should be obtained to evaluate for its involvement (eg, hypophysitis, tumors, metastases, empty sella syndrome).

Management



Management of AI focuses on stabilizing the patient, hormone replacement, and addressing the underlying cause.

Acute adrenal insufficiency



Adrenal crisis is a life-threatening condition requiring immediate intervention before diagnostic evaluation can safely occur.  Key components of management include:



Emergency measures



  • Fluid resuscitation:  aggressive fluid resuscitation to correct volume depletion
  • High-dose glucocorticoid therapy:  hydrocortisone or dexamethasone


Subacute measures



  • Identify and treat precipitating factors (eg, infection).
  • If no known history of AI, measure serum cortisol and ACTH to determine if primary or central.
  • Taper IV glucocorticoids.  Oral hydrocortisone (in divided doses) is preferred because it has both glucocorticoid (major) and mineralocorticoid (minor) effects.  In patients with primary AI, hydrocortisone often does not have adequate mineralocorticoid replacement, so fludrocortisone (a synthetic mineralocorticoid) is usually added (for hyponatremia/hyperkalemia, orthostatic hypotension).

Chronic adrenal insufficiency



Management of chronic AI is similar to acute AI except with no need for emergency measures.  In females, DHEA replacement should be considered for symptoms of androgen deficiency (eg, low libido).  Importantly, in patients with both AI and central hypothyroidism, administering thyroid hormone without adequate glucocorticoid replacement can precipitate adrenal crisis (by increasing cortisol metabolism).



Patients with chronic AI require increased glucocorticoid dosage during periods of stress (eg, illness, surgery, trauma) to prevent adrenal crisis.  The risk of HPA axis suppression and perioperative management (

Differential diagnosis



Given that the symptoms of AI can be nonspecific, several conditions may mimic AI.



Mimickers of chronic adrenal insufficiency



  • Hypothyroidism:  Can also cause fatigue, weakness, and hyponatremia, but hypotension and hyperkalemia are absent.
  • Chronic fatigue syndrome:  Can cause similar subjective symptoms without hypotension or electrolyte abnormalities.


Mimickers of acute adrenal insufficiency



  • Sepsis:  Can also cause cardiovascular collapse, mental status changes, hypoglycemia, and hyperkalemia (if renal failure is present).
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis:  Can also cause hypotension (volume depletion), abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, confusion, and hyperkalemia (acidosis causes potassium to shift out of cells)  However, hyperglycemia is nearly universally seen (although rarely can have euglycemic presentation).
  • Anaphylaxis:  Can also cause hypotension, nausea/vomiting, and confusion, but hyponatremia and hyperkalemia are not typical.

Summary



Adrenal insufficiency (AI) presents a spectrum of symptoms ranging from insidious fatigue to life-threatening adrenal crisis (eg, cardiovascular collapse).  Primary AI is usually due to autoimmune adrenalitis, although tuberculosis is also a common cause worldwide.  Central (secondary/tertiary) AI is usually due to suppression of the HPA axis from exogenous glucocorticoids.  Diagnosis requires recognizing key clinical features, such as hypotension and electrolyte disturbances, alongside specific laboratory findings including low cortisol levels.  Differentiating primary from central AI through ACTH testing is crucial for identifying the underlying etiology, and imaging of the adrenals or pituitary are often necessary.



Management centers on appropriate hormone replacement, with hydrocortisone as the preferred glucocorticoid and fludrocortisone for mineralocorticoid replacement in primary AI.  Patients must be educated on stress dosing to prevent adrenal crises during illness or surgery.  Long-term care involves regular monitoring of symptoms, electrolytes, and bone density, as well as screening for associated autoimmune conditions in primary AI.
